body:
There are already features expose by `log` and `tracing` to control the log level by compiling out levels not wanted.

It's also possible to change it at runtime with the right environment variable, or when you build the app by setting the log filter
That was my rough understanding. I think this is largely a documentation problem then.

body: Where should this piece of documentation live in?
I think module docs for bevy_log.
@Lyndon-Mackay has written up a book style guide to logging in Bevy that's a good starting point for this: https://github.com/Lyndon-Mackay/bevy_logging/

> [@Lyndon-Mackay](https://github.com/Lyndon-Mackay) has written up a book style guide to logging in Bevy that's a good starting point for this: https://github.com/Lyndon-Mackay/bevy_logging/

Thank you was about to post this myself

I am willing to add to the official documentation. 

I think just an example of the like `filter: "warn,my_crate=info,my_crate::a_module=trace".to_string(),` could go a long way.

Maybe a brief overview of the tracing levels.

Technically Tracing could change stuff underneath us but I don't think that is likely considering how widely it is used.


I think sending the users straight to Tracing where lots of the complexity comes from setting up subscribers,layers, and dealing with async, the documentation explains everything but Tracing is IMO deceptively complex and we should start with a quick example.

22222

> I think sending the users straight to Tracing where lots of the complexity comes from setting up subscribers,layers, and dealing with async, the documentation explains everything but Tracing is IMO deceptively complex and we should start with a quick example.

I've gone to the point of patching bevy to remove tracing from builds, feature gating most logging calls, removal of all trace points and replacing with optionally enabled log crate. I'm also strongly against library code dictating how logging should happen.

> > I think sending the users straight to Tracing where lots of the complexity comes from setting up subscribers,layers, and dealing with async, the documentation explains everything but Tracing is IMO deceptively complex and we should start with a quick example.
> 
> I've gone to the point of patching bevy to remove tracing from builds, feature gating most logging calls, removal of all trace points and replacing with optionally enabled log crate. I'm also strongly against library code dictating how logging should happen.

I am unsure about your last sentence.

Disabling the logging plugin and using your own is a relatively simple exercise (I describe it in my book).

Feature gating as you have done is not very fine grained and/or is lots of work.

I think users are better off just filtering out the logs they don't care about and selectively re-enabling.

Its fairly straight forward to filter out library code.

To quote some document changes I will propose once 0.15 is released.

> For a quick setup that enables all your loggings,while not showing all your dependencies log data
> you can configuere the plugin as below.
>
> ```rs no_run
> fn main() {
>     App::new()
>         .add_plugins(DefaultPlugins.set(LogPlugin {
>             filter: "warn,my_crate=trace".to_string(), //specific filters
>             level: Level::TRACE,//Change this to be globally change levels
>             ..Default::default()
>         }))
>         .add_systems(Startup, setup)
>         .run();
> }```

There is further instructions on putting your own logging in that book.
(my proposed documentation changes will not reference my book.)
